Oh, one Christmas was so like another,

Mistletoe howled from the gas brackets in all the front parlours.
There were sherry and walnuts and bottled beer and crackers by the dessert spoons,
And cats in their furibolds watched the fires,
And high-heaped fire spat, all ready for the chestnuts and the melon pokers.
Uncles sat in the front parlours without their collars,
Trying their new cigars, holding them judiciously at arm's length,
Returning them to their mouths, then holding them out again as though waiting for the explosion.
And a few small aunts, not wanted in the kitchen, or anywhere else for that matter,
Sat on the very edges of their chairs, poised and brittle,
Afraid to break like faded cups and saucers.

Always on Christmas night there was music.
An uncle played the fiddle, a cousin sang cherry-ripe,
an uncle sang Drake's drum. It was very warm in the little house.
Auntie Hannah, who had got on to the parsnip wine,
sang a song about bleeding hearts and death.

up the long, steadily falling night.

What's the history of the Seattle Welsh Choir?
It was formed in 1984.
It actually grew out of the Seattle Welsh Language Group.
The language group wanted something to practice the diction of the Welsh music and the Welsh words.
So they formed a choir and started singing.
And it's grown. I think the original membership was about 12.
We're up to 35 now.
Well, that's wonderful.
How often do you rehearse?
Every week, Wednesday night, 7.30, Lake City Presbyterian Church.
And who's the coach for the language?
That's a good question because there are several.
And they're all dialect different.
I was going to say, do they all agree?
No, they don't all agree.
We have a consensus.
Where does the Welsh language come from?
Do we know?
It's roots?
It's the oldest living language in Europe.
The Welsh language is still alive in Wales.
About 20% of the population speak it back in Wales.
And that number is growing.
And it's, excuse me, I'm not a Welsh language expert, but it's very old.
It comes out of what's called the Brythonic tree of languages.
Gaelic comes out of the same tree.
The Irish and the Scottish came, but they emerged at different times.
But Welsh is the oldest one that's still spoken as a language.
And it seems that the Welsh people claim most of the consonants.
There's one or two vowels.
When the consonants join together into two Ds and two Ls, it becomes difficult.
Well, that's really amazing.
